On 6/11/02 8:03 AM, "Mark Meyers" <markm@...> wrote:


>> 
>> 
> The problem is solved, but I gave it just as an example of what can go
> wrong.
> 
> But to elaborate a bit (situation simplified to the bare essentials):
> a ContainerObject is created and added to a set, which triggers an event of
> type "object added" starting from a top level object of type Design.
> The Gui detects that and creates a ContainerObjectView instance on the
> ContainerObject and then registers that view as a listener to the Design
> instance. The java.util.Set of listeners has an object added (the
> ContainerObjectView instance) while there is still an java.util.Iterator in
> use over the Design's listeners, which causes a
> ConcurrentModificationException.
> The tricky bit is that this will never happen when the Gui is not attached
> as a listener to the Design.
> The solution is to clone the Set or to use toArray(), and iterating over the
> copy instead.
> 


Is this the "norm" in the type of applications that you write?

We can write tests for the gui, no doubt about it - it's just I question how
useful such tests are when weighed against the effort that must go in to
writing them. You hit upon a case where it's not an option - you have to
test the gui.
